Efficient virtual reality design of quiet underwater shells
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 30 September 2005

Efficient virtual reality design of quiet underwater shells

  • W. Akl1 &
  • A. Baz2 

Virtual Reality volume 9, pages57–69(2005)Cite this article

  • 133 Accesses

  • 2 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Efficient computational tools are developed to model, visualize, and feel the structural-acoustics of shells in a virtual reality environment. These tools aim at building the structural-acoustic models of shells from an array of basic building blocks including: beams, shells, and stiffeners. The concepts of finite element analysis, sub-structuring, model reduction, meta-modeling, and parallel computations form the main steps to be followed for building simplified computational models of complex shell systems. The resulting models are particularly suitable for the efficient application of multi-criteria optimization techniques in order to select the optimal design parameters of these complex shell systems. The developed integrated analysis tools enable the engineers to design complex systems in a cost effective and a timely manner. Furthermore, engineers will be immersed in an audio-visually coupled tele-operated environment whereby direct interaction and control of the design process can be achieved. In this manner, the behavior of synthetic models of shells can be monitored by literally walking through the shell and adjusting its design parameters as needed to ensure optimal performance while satisfying design and operational requirements. For example, engineers can move electronic wands to vary the number, size, type, and location of stiffeners in the shell, monitor the resulting structural-acoustic visually or by haptic feedback and simultaneously listen to the radiated sound pressure field. Such manipulations of the virtual shells in the scene are carried out while the engineer is navigating through and around the shell to ensure that the vibration and sound levels, at any critical locations, are within the acceptable limits. The developed integrated approach also serves as a means for virtual training of students and engineers on designing and operating complex smart structures on the site as well as through collaborative efforts with other virtual reality sites. Such unique capability will enable engineers to design prototypes of expensive vehicles without building them. Examples of these vehicles include aircraft, submersibles, torpedoes, and others that can share this virtual experience and can be profoundly impacted upon by the proposed approach. The presented optimal design approach is implemented in the Virtual Reality CAVE Laboratory at the University of Maryland that is controlled by an eight parallel processor Silicon Graphics Infinite Reality (ONYX2) computer.

Introduction

Considerable interest has been shown in studying the dynamics of stiffened underwater shells in an attempt to attenuate the vibration and noise radiation from these shells into the surrounding environment (Photiadis et al. 1997; Skelton and James 1997; Junger and Feit 1997).

In 2000, Ruzzene and Baz (2000) presented a finite element model of the vibration and sound radiation from fluid-loaded shells with multiple undamped and damped stiffeners. The model is used to select the optimal design parameters of the passive stiffeners in order to minimize the structural acoustic signature of the shell while minimizing the weight and cost of the stiffeners (Akl et al. 2002). The finite element model of Ruzzene and Baz (2000) has also been extended to investigate the effect of augmenting the stiffeners with active components on the sound radiation and power flow characteristics of thin-cylindrical shells Ruzzene and Baz (2000). Based on that model, Akl et al. (2002) developed a rational multi-criteria optimization approach to determine the optimal design parameters of fluid-loaded shells with active stiffeners. The adopted approach aims simultaneously at minimizing the shell vibration, associated sound radiation, weight of the stiffening rings, the control energy and the stiffened shell cost while maximizing the controllability and observability indices.

In the present study, the emphasis is placed on enhancing the computational efficiency of selecting the optimal design parameters of fluid-loaded shells with active periodic stiffeners using sub-structuring, parallel processing, and meta-modeling techniques. With such efficient computational techniques, the speed of execution of the design process is enhanced about 20-fold and it became possible to implement this process in real-time in the virtual reality facility at the University of Maryland.

This paper is organized in seven sections and one appendix. In Sect. 1, a brief introduction is given. Section 2 gives an overview of the optimal design problem of shells with active stiffeners and summarizes the objectives of this paper. The finite element model that describes the dynamics of the shell/active stiffeners and the surrounding fluid domain is presented briefly in Sect. 3. The sub-structuring, parallel processing, and meta-modeling techniques are presented in Sect. 4.The formulation of the multi-criteria optimization problem is presented in Sect. 5. Section 6 presents the results of the optimization process with and without the computational enhancements along with comparisons with the performance of plain shells. Section 7 summarizes the main results of this work and gives some recommendations for future research.

Overview and objectives

The vibration and sound radiation of a fluid-loaded shell are controlled, in the present study, by providing the shell with active stiffening rings as shown in Fig. 1.The selection process of the optimal design parameters of the active stiffeners is carried out in two steps. In the first step, the optimal cross-sectional geometry (width a and depth b) and spacing (s) [or the number of stiffeners (N s )] of the stiffeners are determined as if the stiffeners were completely passive. In the second step, the obtained optimal parameters of the passive stiffeners are used as a basis for computing the optimal placement strategy of a single actuator on the stiffeners (B a ) as well as the optimal control gains (K d ). Such a two-step process guarantees that the shell performance with not only the passive stiffeners is optimal but the performance with the active stiffeners is also optimal. In this manner, the adopted two-step design approach ensures a robust performance of the stiffened shell even when the active controller fails to operate.

Details of the first design step are reported by Akl et al. (2002) whereby the design parameters of the passive stiffeners are selected to minimize the vibration and noise radiation, weight of the stiffening rings, and the stiffened shell cost. Emphasis is placed here on developing the second design step in order to select the optimum design parameters of the active stiffeners. These parameters will simultaneously minimize the shell vibration, associated sound radiation, and the control energy.

Solution of the resulting multi-criteria optimization problem requires the interaction between the structural-acoustics finite element model, described in Sect. 3, as well as the sub-structuring, parallel processing, and meta-modeling techniques described in Sect. 4. Figure 2 shows an outline of such an interaction.

Finite element Of fluid-loaded stiffened shells

The finite element presented in this section is based on the work of Djoudi and Bahai (2003) which considers linear and nonlinear analyses of shallow shell elements. In their work, a strain-based approach is used to generate the shape functions of the element. This enables higher-order polynomial terms for the displacement to be used without the need for the inclusion of additional degrees of freedom such as internal degrees of freedom that are not associated with the generalized forces. Furthermore, the resulting shape functions will satisfy the exact representation of the strain-free rigid-body modes of the displacements. With such advantages, only a 4-noded element with five degrees of freedom per node is needed to accurately capture the dynamics of the shell with good rate of convergence. Note that in this case, the components of the strain fields are not independent of each other but are linked by the constitutive strain–displacement relationships.

Adding stiffeners, longitudinally or radially, to the shell has proven to improve the stiffness greatly without increasing its weight significantly. Stiffeners can be either passive or actively controlled as developed by Ruzzene and Baz (2000a, b). The dynamics of the stiffened shells have been studied extensively, for example, by Egle and Sewall (1968), where ring stiffeners or longitudinal stringers were treated as discrete elements. This allows the development of an accurate model with small number of stiffeners. In 1987, Mead and Bardell (1987) studied the free vibration of circumferentially stiffened thin-cylindrical shells. In 1994, Sinha and Mukhopadhyay (1994) added a new flexibility to the designer, by allowing the stiffeners to occupy any arbitrary position and orientation other than being forced to lie in the direction of the curvature of the shell. Nayak and Bandyopadhyay (2002) studied the vibration analysis of conoidal shells with both concentric and eccentric stiffeners.

In 2002, Akl et al. (2000a, b) optimized the performance of stiffened shells using multi-criteria optimization techniques by taking into consideration the structural vibration, sound radiation, weight, and cost as the basic optimization criteria.

In the present study, the works of Craggs (1971), Everstine (1981), Skelton and James (1997), and Ruzzene and Baz (2000a, b) have been used to guide the development of the effect of the structure–fluid interaction.

Thus, the equations governing the dynamics of interacting shell and fluid elements are given as follows:

$$ \hbox{Shell:} \quad {\left[ {M_{s}} \right]}\,{\left\{{\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{\delta}_{s}} \right\}} + {\left[ {K_{s}} \right]}\,{\left\{{\delta _{s}} \right\}} = \tfrac{1}{{\rho _{0}}}{\left[ \Omega \right]}\,{\left\{{p_{e}} \right\}} + \{f\}, $$
(1)

and

$$ \hbox{Fluid:} \quad {\left[ {M_{A}} \right]}\,{\left\{{\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{p}_{e}} \right\}} + {\left[ {K_{A}} \right]}\,{\left\{{p_{e}} \right\}} = - {\left[ \Omega \right]}^{T}\,\,{\left\{{\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{\delta}_{s}} \right\}},$$

where {δ s } and {p e } denote the nodal deflection and vectors. Also, [ M) and [ K) denote the mass and stiffness matrices with subscripts s and A defining the structure and acoustic media. The interaction between the structure and the fluid is defined by the coupling matrix [ Ω ]. In (1), ρ o denotes the fluid density and {f} is the load vector given by

$$\{f\}= \{f_{e}\}+\{f_{c}\} $$
(2)

with {f e } and {f c } denoting the external and control forces respectively. The control force vector is generated using a velocity feedback control law such that:

$$\{f_{c}\} = - K_{d} [B_{a}) \left\{\ifmmode\expandafter\dot\else\expandafter\.\fi{\delta}_{s} \right\}$$
(3)

with K d is the control gain and [B a ] is the placement matrix of the active stiffeners.

In a matrix form, (1) reduces to the following equation for the coupled shell/fluid system:

$${\left( {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{[M_{s} ]}} & {0} \\ {{{\left[ \Omega \right]}^{T} }} & {{[M_{A} ]}} \\ \end{array} } \right)}{\left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{\delta }_{s} }} \\ {{\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{p}_{e} }} \\ \end{array} } \right\}} + {\left( {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{[K_{s} ]}} & {{ - \tfrac{1}{{\rho _{0} }}{\left[ \Omega \right]}}} \\ {0} & {{[K_{A} ]}} \\ \end{array} } \right)}{\left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{\delta _{s} }} \\ {{p_{e} }} \\ \end{array} } \right\}} = {\left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {f} \\ {0} \\ \end{array} } \right\}}.$$
(4)

In a compact form, the above equation reduces to:

$$[M]{\left\{{\ifmmode\expandafter\ddot\else\expandafter\"\fi{q}} \right\}} + [K]\,{\left\{q \right\}} = {\left\{F \right\}},$$
(5)

where, [K) is the overall stiffness matrix, [M) is the overall mass matrix, [F) is the generalized force vector, and {q} is the generalized coordinates [{q}= {δ s  p e }T] of the entire shell/fluid system.

It is important to note that using (5) as a basis for computing the shell response and the vibration/acoustic metrics which are necessary for selecting the optimal design parameters of the shell poses serious computational challenges. Such challenges are attributed to the large number of degrees of freedom of the entire shell/fluid system which make the computation of the eigenvalue problem and system response very intensive and time consuming. The computational difficulties become particularly evident when the implementation is carried out on a single processor and in the conventional serial manner. In Sect. 4, efficient numerical techniques are presented to enhance the computational efficiency through the use of sub-structuring, parallel processing, and meta-modeling.

Sub-structuring, parallel processing, and Meta-modeling

Sub-structuring

The order of the stiffness and mass matrices that describe the dynamics of the coupled shell and surrounding fluid medium is reduced by condensing the degrees of freedom associated with the internal nodes (interior coordinates) as shown in Fig. 3 (Craig et al.1968; Hale et al. 1982; Leung et al.1993; Craig et al. (2000). Only the degrees of freedom that are of primary importance will be retained in the reduced order models. In the present study, the inter-sub-structural boundary nodes are considered as the master degrees of freedom and denoted by m, while the interior nodes are considered the slave ones and are denoted by s.

Equation (4) of the shell/fluid system is rewritten for harmonic excitation with frequency ω as follows:

$${\left[ {[K] - \omega ^{2} [M]} \right]}{\left\{q \right\}} = {\left\{F \right\}}.$$
(6)

The generalized coordinate vector {q} is partitioned into two vectors: {q s } and {q m } corresponding to slave and master nodes respectively. Accordingly, equation (6) is arranged as follows:

$${\left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{K_{{mm}} - \omega ^{2} M_{{mm}} }} & {{K_{{ms}} - \omega ^{2} M_{{ms}} }} \\ {{K_{{sm}} - \omega ^{2} M_{{sm}} }} & {{K_{{ss}} - \omega ^{2} M_{{ss}} }} \\ \end{array} } \right]} \cdot {\left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{q_{m} }} \\ {{q_{s} }} \\ \end{array} } \right\}} = {\left\{ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} {{F_{m} }} \\ {{F_{s} }} \\ \end{array} } \right\}}.$$
(7)

Performing the classical static condensation, i.e., neglecting the inertia terms, the slave degrees of freedom can be written in terms of the master degrees of freedom as

$$\{q_{s}\} = [K_{ss})^{-1}.(\{F_{s}\}-[K_{sm}). \{q_{m}\}).$$
(8)

Substituting {q s } from equation (8) into (7) results in:

$${\left[ {K^{{*s}}_{{mm}}} \right]}.{\left\{{q_{m}} \right\}} = {\left\{{F^{{*s}}_{m}} \right\}},$$
(9)

where

$$\left[ {K_{mm}^{*s} } \right] = \left[ {K_{mm} } \right] - \left[ {K_{ms} } \right]\left[ {{\text{K}}_{ss} } \right]^{ - 1} \left[ {K_{sm} } \right]\quad {\text{and}}\quad \left\{ {F_m^{*s} } \right\} = \left\{ {F_m } \right\} - \left[ {K_{ms} } \right]\left[ {K_{ss} } \right]^{ - 1} \cdot \left\{ {F_s } \right\}$$
(10)

with [ K *s mm ] and {F *s m }denoting the reduced stiffness matrix and the reduced load vector.

Equation (9) represents the reduced system of equations of the master degrees of freedom {q m }. By solving this system and using (8) the slave degrees of freedom can also be obtained.

Parallel computation

Implementation of the finite element model of the entire fluid-loaded shell on a single processor is a rather challenging problem. However, by sub-structuring the shell/fluid system as described in Sect. 4.1, the problem becomes readily suitable for parallel processing as the models of each sub-structure can be independently manipulated on separate processors and the obtained results can be assembled on another processor to compute the frequency response of the assembly. With such a parallel processing approach, the computational burden can be significantly reduced.

Examples of successful and efficient implementations of parallel computation are numerous. For example, Ray et al. (1997) presented a shared memory parallel implementation of a finite element formulation for unsteady interior flows with fluid-structure interactions. Three different platforms are used; CRAY C90®, SGI Onyx® and SGI Power Challenge®. It was found that the computational speed was the highest when using the SGI Onyx with eight processors. Dong and Karniadakis (2004) presented a hybrid two-level parallel paradigm with MPI/OpenMP to take full advantage of the hierarchical structures arising from the spectral/hp discretizations of CFD problems. Four different platforms are used; IBM SP3, SGI Origin 2000, Compaq Alpha Cluster and Intel IA64 Cluster. It is found that with the same number of processors, the hybrid model with 2 threads per process performed the best on the SGI Origin and the IA64 cluster. Other examples include the work of Cros (1998) and Mackens and Voss (1999) whereby parallel computing is used in modal synthesis and solution of the eigenvalue problems of dynamical systems.

In this study, the parallel computation is carried out at the Virtual Reality Laboratory at the University of Maryland on a Silicon Graphics computer (SGI-Onyx2) that has eight parallel processors (R10000 from MIPS Technologies). Each processor has peak data transfer rate of 3.2 GB per  s to secondary cache. Also, the Onyx2 system has distributed shared-memory (DSM) with the main memory partitioned among processors but accessible to and shared by all of the processors. The Onyx2 architecture allows for maximum rate of data transfer between processors. In addition, it has extremely low latency, since most of the frequently accessed data are physically stored in memory slots very close to the processors, which is either the primary cache located in the processor itself or the secondary cache very close to it, which is 4-MB size.

The parallel computation utilizes the MATLAB parallelization toolkit (MPI) which consists of a collection of routines that enable simple means of parallelizing any MATLAB code. The toolkit is intended primarily for algorithms that are simple to parallelize, where the amount of inter-process communication is low. The main concept of this toolbox is based on the master/slave paradigm, which enables forking a different MATLAB process from the parent one, and passing all the required data and instructions to, without blocking the original flow of the parent process. This, however, does not guarantee that each of the processes utilizes a different processor on a multi-processor machine. Accordingly, appropriate modifications are considered to ensure that the application is distributed uniformly among these processors. This is achieved by running the MATLAB application from a C++ code using “MATLAB engines”. This was particularly suitable for the current application, as for the virtual reality model being developed, all the visualization is accomplished using C++ code taking advantage of the Performer® libraries for manipulating graphics inside virtual reality environments.

The MATLAB engine acts as a demon that runs in the background, and is ready to accept variables from the calling process and run any valid MATLAB operation. The calling process is coded in C++, and includes proper initialization code for the engine and proper variable declaration to be passed to that engine. The processing flowchart is shown in Fig. 4 indicating the N slave processes corresponding to N sub-structures.

Parallel processing of visualization

A description of the “virtual world” is encapsulated in the scene graph, and a view into the world is described by a Channel. This view is rendered by an OpenGL Performer software pipeline, Pipe, into a window, PipeWindow, on a selected screen. This path of operation is as shown in Fig. 5 [SGI Performer® developer’s guide].

Scene graph

A scene graph may be considered as the environment where all the graphical objects are resident. Such graphical objects might be any three-dimensionally modeled elements, as for example the underwater shell, the stiffeners of that shell, or even an interactive menu to select the modeling parameters from. Each independent element in the scene graph is called a node, which might hold, for example the data for any geometry.

Different node types provide mechanisms for grouping, animation, and other concepts that are applied when the scene graph is updated in each time frame to put the whole model into action. The nodes in a scene graph are arranged in a hierarchy, as shown in Fig. 6.

The hierarchy of nodes can be illustrated by the following example. If an underwater shell is modeled in a virtual environment, which will present the parent node in a scene, then the stiffeners, for example, can be a child node attached to the parent one. The skin of the shell can be also considered as another child node. The entire scene graph represents all of the data in the model’s graphical database.

Channels

A channel is equivalent to a camera moving throughout the scene. The scene graph encapsulates all of the visual data in the scene, whereas the channel contains only that visual information that is visible to the viewer; the channel shows a slice of the scene from a specified perspective.

Pipe and window

The pipe renders the visual data in the viewing frustum to a window. The pipe is the software abstraction of the hardware graphics pipeline. Rendering of the scene occurs in three stages:

  1. 1.

    APP updates the location and shape of geometries and updates the viewing location and orientation.

  2. 2.

    CULL determines geometries in the scene which are visible.

  3. 3.

    DRAW renders all visible geometries.

Each stage is potentially a separate process. Therefore, for a multi-processor workstation maximum performance can be achieved by running each of these processes on a different processor; for example for a 3-processor workstation, three consecutive frames can be processed at the same time as shown in Fig. 7.

Hence, the basic components of the OpenGL/Performer code include:

  1. 1.

    Initializing OpenGL performer

  2. 2.

    Acquiring a pipe

  3. 3.

    Creating a channel and window

  4. 4.

    Associating the channel with the appropriate window

  5. 5.

    Loading the scene graph and associate it with the channel

  6. 6.

    Positioning the channel(s) and updating the scene

  7. 7.

    Drawing the scene

  8. 8.

    Creating the simulation loop to return to step 6.

The simulation loop drives the application. Its actions are carried out in the APP process. The simulation loop repeats endlessly until the application exits. Figure 8 shows that the simulation loop generally has three steps:

  1. 1.

    Update the appearance, shape, and location of the objects in the scene.

  2. 2.

    Update the position and orientation of the camera in the scene.

  3. 3.

    Redraw the scene.

According to the aforementioned brief preview of the visualization process using SGI Performer®, it is clear that all the analysis elements will go to the APP process, where we first, select the modeling parameters of the active shell under investigation, position the shell in a proper viewing spectrum and finally pass the selected set of parameters to the “computational engine” to solve the finite element model of the active shell and obtain the vibration displacement of the shell structure and the acoustic field in the surrounding environment. By doing so, we would have abstracted the visualization/analysis procedure into two parts; the first one is concerned with drawing the scene graph and the second part is computing the frequency responses of the shell as shown in Fig. 9. The Performer® will then take care of the rest of the visualization procedure.

Development of the Meta-models

Statistical techniques are employed to construct an approximation or meta-model, i.e., “model of the model” of the coupled substructures code that is used in lieu of the actual code in order to facilitate the optimization and exploration of the various design concepts of fluid-loaded shell. In this regard, the response surface models (1995, 1993) are used. To build these meta-models, there are four major considerations

  1. (a)

    choosing an experimental design for generating the data

  2. (b)

    choosing a model to represent the data

  3. (c)

    fitting the model to the computed data

  4. (d)

    verifying the predictions of the meta-model.

Figure 10 shows the design space of the active shell in the plane of the two design variables x 1 and x 2 which are the actuator location (B a ) and the control gain (K d ). Small number of combinations (n c ) of the design variable vector x i = {x 1 x 2} T i , with i=1,..., n c , is used to generate the design objective vector \(Y = \left\{ {y_1 ,...,y_{n_c } } \right\}^{\text{T}} \) using the sub-structured finite element model. The set of \(X = \left\{ {x_1 ,...,x_{n_c } } \right\}^{\text{T}} \) and Y are then used to generate quadratic meta-model that simulates the response surface of the shell such that:

$$y_{i} = \beta _{0} + \beta _{1} x_{{1_{i}}} + \beta _{2} x_{{2_{i}}} + \beta _{3} x^{2}_{{1_{i}}} + \beta _{4} x^{2}_{{2_{i}}} + \beta _{5} x_{{1_{i}}} x_{{2_{i}}} \quad \hbox{ for }\;i = 1, \ldots, n_{c}.$$
(11)

Accordingly for all the test points, one can generate the following matrix equation

$$\varvec{Y}= [\varvec{A}) \theta ,$$
(12)

where \(Y = \left\{ {y_1 ,...,y_{n_c } } \right\}^{\text{T}} \) = the design objective vector, θ={β0 β1 β2 β3 β4 β5}T= vector of regression parameters, and the matrix [A) is given by

$$[A] = \left[ {\begin{array}{*{20}c} 1 & {x_{1_1 } } & {x_{2_1 } } & {x_{1_1 }^2 } & {x_{2_1 }^2 } & {x_{1_1 } x_{2_1 } } \\ \cdot\cdot & \cdot\cdot & \cdot\cdot & \cdot\cdot & \cdot\cdot & \cdots\cdot\cdot \\ 1 & {x_{1_{n_c } } } & {x_{2_{n_c } } } & {x_{1_{n_c } }^2 } & {x_{2_{n_c } }^2 } & {x_{1_{n_c } } x_{2_n } } \\ \end{array} } \right].$$
(13)

The regression vector θ is determined to minimize the square of the errors between the metal-model predictions and the finite element model predictions such that

$$\theta = ([\varvec{A})^{\rm T} [\varvec{A}))^{-1} [\varvec{A})^{\rm T} \varvec{Y}.$$
(14)

Then, the meta-model given by (10) can be used in the optimization process instead of the computationally intensive solution of the finite element (5). Figure 11 shows the main components of the meta-modeling computational strategy.

Such an approach is particularly important in the design of large underwater vehicles because direct use of conventional finite element analysis codes would be extremely time consuming and computationally intensive as is evident in the study of Akl et al. ((2000a, b) during the design of quiet underwater shells. It is important here to note that the validation of the results of the meta-modeling is carried out using the full-order finite element analysis before sub-structural condensation.

Multi-criteria design optimization

Multi-criteria design optimization (MDO) strategies are employed to optimize the performance of the active shells using the computationally efficient techniques presented in Sect. 4. The optimization strategies aim at selecting the optimum location of one active stiffener and its control gain in order to minimize the structural vibration, sound radiation, and the control energy.

Mathematically, the multi-criteria optimization problem is formulated as follows:

such that\(B_{{a_{{\min}}}} \leq {B}_{a}\leq B_{{a_{{\max}}}}\) and \(K_{{d_{{\min}}}} \leq {K}_{d} \leq K_{{d_{{\max}}}} \)

In (15), f 1= the maximum amplitude of vibration, f 2= the maximum amplitude of sound pressure level, and f 3= the maximum control energy.

The search for the optimum solution is carried out in two steps using a Pareto optimum search followed by a min-max search. Such a two-step search is essential as the Pareto optimum search does not provide a single solution but a set of so-called “Non-inferior solutions”, then the min-max optimum search finds an optimal solution from the Pareto optimum set (Osyczka (1984).

Each of the optimum search techniques requires the evaluation of the “ideal solution” which consists of the optimum values for the individual objective functions. A random generator generates sets of the design variables covering the feasible search space satisfying the design constraints. The generated sets are then manipulated by the Pareto optimum search and the min-max search to determine the optimal design.

Numerical results

Predictions of complete finite element model

A fixed-free shell is modeled using the developed finite element model (UMD). The predictions of the model are validated against the prediction of ANSYS® software package. The shell considered has the following parameters: radius=0.074 m, length=0.305 m, thickness=0.18 mm, Young’s modulus=68.258 GN/m2, Poisson’s ratio=0.3, density=2,714 kg/m3, number of elements in the longitudinal direction=16, and number of elements in the circumferential direction=24. Table 1 summarizes the comparison between the UMD and ANSYS models for the first four natural frequencies. Excellent agreement is evident between the two models.

Figure 12 shows comparisons between the UMD and ANSYS models for the first three mode shapes. Excellent agreement is also evident between the predictions of the two models.

The number of the circumferential elements was chosen so as to compromise between the model accuracy and the processing speed aimed at. Therefore, the values of the shell vibration amplitude as well as the sound pressure level in the acoustic medium were calculated for different number of circumferential elements. The results are shown in Fig. 13 when the number of longitudinal elements=32 and fluid radial elements=8. The fluid elements are brick elements, i.e., 8-noded elements with one degree of freedom per node which is the fluid pressure.

Accordingly, the fluid domain is assumed to be finite and bounded.

It can be seen that the accuracy improvement between 24 and 32 elements is almost negligible. Therefore, 24 circumferential elements are used in the remaining parts of this paper.

Processing time

The processing time for the multi-processed sub-structure case was calculated and compared with the case of modeling the entire shell as a single structure using the same workstation. The comparison is carried out for different number of circumferential elements, while keeping the number of longitudinal and radial acoustic elements fixed to 32 and 8, respectively. Table 2 summarizes the results of this comparison.

When modeling the shell with 32 circumferential elements as a single structure, the MATLAB ran out of memory and could not complete the process.

Optimization of the actively-controlled stiffened shell

Full-order model with conventional optimization

First, the optimal location of the active stiffener and the control gain are determined by using the full-order finite element model and the conventional min-max optimization algorithm (Osyczka 1984). The obtained optimal parameters and associated computation time will serve as a data for quantifying the accuracy and the computational efficiency of the enhancement techniques of sub-structuring, parallel processing, and meta-modeling described in Section 4.

For the shell example under consideration, 15 passive stiffeners are installed with only one being active. Hence, we have 15 different alternatives for the actuator location, i.e., B amin=1 and B amax=15. Seven different values of the control gain K d are used in addition to the uncontrolled case where the gain is equal to zero. Hence, a full data set with 120 entries was generated as shown in Fig. 14. The optimal parameters are B a = 1 and K d = 1.38 105 Ns/m with the optimal weighted objective function of 0.947. The associated computation time was 720 min.

Sub-structured model with meta-modeling optimization

Figure 15a shows the test points used to generate the quadratic meta-model of shell performance as obtained from the solution of the sub-structured model. Figure 15b displays the contours of the objective function on the plane of the design parameters B a and K d . The obtained values of the optimal parameters are B a = 1 and K d = 1.69 105 Ns/m with the optimal weighted objective function of 0.961. The associated computation time was 100 min., i.e., a time reduction of 7.2 as compared to time needed for the optimization of the full-order model.

Implementation in the virtual reality environment (CAVE)

The performance of the passive and active shells is validated in the virtual reality environment (CAVE) at the University of Maryland to enable the designer to become an integral part of the computer-aided design process and the design loop. This is very important as all Multi-criteria design optimization (MDO) strategies yield many optimum solutions [Pareto Optimal Solutions, e.g., Leondes (1999) and the designer by being immersed in the virtual reality environment can listen to and view the attributes of each of these solutions in real time. Accordingly, the designer can gain considerable insight about the physics of the system, favor one design over another or modify the design Figures of Merits to capture the physics of the problem. Such powerful interaction can only be possible when the engineer is fully immersed in an audio-visually coupled tele-operated virtual environment where the physical performance of a complex structure can be monitored by literally walking through the shell and adjusting its design parameters as needed to ensure optimal performance while satisfying design and operational requirements.

Figure 16 shows the effect of stiffening the shell on its vibration characteristics when the shell is excited at 100 Hz at its end inside the virtual reality environment (CAVE). It is evident that stiffening the shell is very effective in attenuating its structural vibration and acoustic radiation.

Figure 16 indicates that the maximum amplitude of radial vibration of the plain shell is 0.656 mm and the maximum sound pressure level is 74.976 dB at a distance of 0.66 m from the surface of the shell. With seven passive stiffeners, the corresponding values are 0.266 mm and 61.149 dB. When the number of stiffeners is increased to 15, the vibration and sound level become 0.220 mm and 56.984 dB. Hence, adding 15 stiffeners has resulted in reducing the amplitude of vibration by a factor of three and improved the attenuation of the sound radiation by 17.99 dB.

Figures 17 and 18 show the shell performance with 1 active stiffener and 14 passive stiffeners as compared to the uncontrolled shell at excitation frequencies of 100 Hz and 500 Hz respectively. At 100 Hz, the use of active control resulted in the attenuation of the maximum amplitude of vibration to 0.21 mm and sound pressure level to 56.6 dB. The corresponding values at 500 Hz excitation are 0.22 mm and 82.2 dB as compared to 0221 mm and 83.03 dB for the uncontrolled case. Note for the plain shell, the corresponding values are 0.77 mm and 106.1 dB.

It is evident that actively stiffening the shell has resulted in attenuating its structural vibration and acoustic radiation. However, more actuators are needed to significantly attenuate the vibration and acoustic metrics.

Conclusion

This paper has presented efficient computational techniques to reduce the processing time for optimizing the performance of fluid-loaded shells with active stiffeners. In these techniques, the shell structure and the surrounding acoustic medium are divided into sub-structures. The reduced stiffness and mass matrices for the sub-structures are calculated independently each on a separate processor of a multi-processor workstation. By assembling the models of the different sub-structures, the master degrees of freedom are computed. These degrees of freedom are then used to calculate the remaining slave degrees of freedom. The entire model is developed and integrated efficiently with a virtual reality environment which is particularly suitable for displaying and manipulating the entire shell assembly. The processing time of the sub-structured model is reduced by more than threefold, for the shell example under consideration, as compared to the processing time of the full-order model on a single processor in a serial manner. Accordingly, the presented approach has resulted in a much faster prediction of the shell response and better utilization of the available resources.

Furthermore, the optimization technique utilized in this study employed a quadratic meta-model of the sub-structured model. The meta-model was calculated using a small sub-set of the feasible design parameters called the “test points.” Optimization of the meta-model yielded a global optimum and optimal parameters which are close to those obtained from the full-order model. However, the obtained results are achieved in one-seventh of the time needed for optimization of the full-order model.

Hence, the total computation time due to applying the sub-structuring, multi-processing and the meta-modeling is found to be about 24- fold smaller than that needed for the optimization of the full-order model. Such a significant reduction of the execution time makes the presented computational techniques into invaluable tools for the efficient design of complex structural systems.

As a natural extension of this study, the calculated set of master degrees of freedom should be used to directly generate the meta-model to further reduce the computational time. Furthermore, the sub-structuring is developed in this study using static condensation and it is natural to extend the development to using dynamic condensation (Soize and Mziou 2003; Takewaki and Uetani 1999) in order to improve the prediction accuracy for higher order modes. Also, the meta-models developed here are deterministic in nature, and other models which are stochastic in nature should be explored as the kriging models (Sakata et al. 2003). Other possible research direction can be to include the effect of parameters uncertainty on the robustness of shell optimization.
